author: lfshr
body:
Using a custom attribute in a PowerShell class causes PowerShell to error with message "An error occurred while creating the pipeline"

Steps to reproduce
------------------

> class CustomAttribute1 : System.Attribute
> {
> }
> 
> class CustomObject1
> {
>     [CustomAttribute1()]
>     $Var1
> }
> 

Expected behavior
-----------------
Creates class with attributed member

Actual behavior
---------------
PowerShell throws "An error occurred while creating the pipeline"

Environment data
----------------
PSVersion                      5.0.10240.16384                                                                                                                                                                       
WSManStackVersion              3.0                                                                                                                                                                                   
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                                                                                                                                                               
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000                                                                                                                                                                       
BuildVersion                   10.0.10240.16384                                                                                                                                                                      
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                                                                                                                                                               
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3

comments.author: lfshr
comments.body: This appears to go deeper than custom Attributes. Custom classes defined in in dll files also do not work! Trying my best to come up with a solution.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I tested the sample in Powershell Core (alpha 15) - it work without a parser error.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
It's a runtime error because we can't resolve the type and don't yet support defining an attribute in PowerShell.

There is no reason this couldn't work though - and that is the basic syntax you'd use (though we'd require an `AttributeUsage` attribute on the attribute class definition.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
It constructs the metadata when an attribute is applied to something.

A blob of metadata has a reference to the constructor (and implicitly the attribute type) and the positional and named arguments for the specific application of the attribute.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
Ah - right click - that's your problem.  Put the repro in a file and run that.

With right click - the attribution definition was seen as one complete statement and run before parsing the next class.

If you pasted (Ctrl+v in Windows PowerShell), then the entire buffer would have been parsed like a single file and I think you'd have seen the problem.
